title: Energy Visions Series – Accelerating the energy transition: What is the role for decarbonized gas?
text:
**Registration for this event is now closed. For any questions, please contact: events@politico.eu**

The European Commission has set its climate vision for 2050, supporting the objective of climate neutrality, and the different pathways proposed for the transition to a net-zero greenhouse gas emissions economy. This includes decarbonization of the energy sector.

In April, more than half of EU countries signed a political declaration on decarbonized gas in which they commit to promote hydrogen and maximize using the existing gas grid to accommodate more low-carbon gas, such as bio-methane and other renewable gases. The move comes as industry tries to embrace the fact that natural gas will need to gradually play a smaller role to meet the EU’s decarbonization path, which is why the sector aims to reposition itself as a provider of renewable gases.

However, not all countries share the same vision for the role of low-carbon gas in the EU’s energy mix, and the Greens warned that the bloc should fully phase out fossil fuels by the middle of this century if wants to meet the Paris Agreement. All eyes are now on the next Commission which is set to propose a legislative reform of the EU’s gas rules to make room for more sources of decarbonized gas.

Questions to be addressed include:

Renewable gas, biomethane, hydrogen and bioLNG, what qualifies as lower-carbon gas? What do we mean by green gas?

What role can decarbonized/green gas play in the energy systems? Will natural gas play a role in the medium and long-term future?

How can cleaner gas help decarbonize industrial, transport and heating sectors? What is the outlook for 2030 and beyond?

Does the EU need more infrastructure for these new sources of green gas?

Do we need to decentralize the gas system as we did for the electricity system?
